Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: Children are about to finish school, and the parent should pick them up
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: The pantry is stocked with kosher ingredients, and alternative snacks are readily available.
Story: I glance at the clock—fifteen minutes until school lets out. My phone buzzes with a reminder: “Pick up the kids.” I grab my keys, but as I pass the kitchen, I hear my youngest’s voice in my head, “Can we have a snack when we get home?” I remember the PTA email: today, the school is handing out treats to celebrate the end of the year. I know from experience that the snacks are rarely kosher, and my kids will be offered cookies and cupcakes before I even arrive. I want to be there, to see their faces light up, to be the parent who never misses a moment. But I also feel the weight of my Jewish identity, the responsibility to teach my children about our traditions, to help them navigate the world while honoring our values. I picture their disappointment if I say no to the treats, their confusion if I let them eat what isn’t kosher. My heart pounds as I stand in the doorway, keys in hand, torn between being the parent who shows up and the Jewish parent who says, “We do things differently.”
